author: Timmyy

description.text:
5 Degree Of Freedom camera mount for Digoo DG-M1Q. Arm can be adapted for any other cameras (Fusion 360 design can be found here: http://a360.co/2vAN0JS).
It's meant to attach camera to aluminum extrusion that can fit M4 square nut (i.e. CR-10).

Following fasteners recommended for assembly:
  • M4 square nut
  • M4 x 16 mm machine screw
  • M4 x 12 mm machine screw
  • M4 x 20 mm machine screw
  • M4 x 30 mm machine screw
  • M4 hex Nut
  • 3 x M4 Thumb Nuts (regular hex nuts can be used instead)
Assembly

Assembly is pretty straight forward.

  • Insert M4x16 screw into "frame mount" and attach M4 square nut slightly just so it stays on very end of the screw.
  • Attach "Frame Mount" to "Bracket A" with M4x30 screw and M4 thumb nut
  • Insert M4 hex nut into "Bracket B" recess (use pliers in needed) and attach to "Bracket A" using M4x12mm screw
  • Attach "Bracket C" to "Bracket B" with M4x20 screw and M4 thumb nut
  • Carefully insert camera body into camera mount. Try not to break it's fragile brackets.
  • Attach "camera mount" to "Bracket C" with M4x25mm screw and M4 thumb nut
  • Finally insert M4 square nut (wiggle it) into aluminum extrusion on your printer where it won't interfere with moving parts and screw in M4x16mm screw until it's secure.
  • Adjust all pivots until camera is pointed where you want it and tighten thumb screws.

All parts other than camera mount were printed in PLA. I recommend printing camera mount in some strong and not too rigid filament (i.e. PETG) as two alms holding camera might break when camera is inserted. Also please flip "camera_mount.stl" cause it's upside-down :)

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Use stronger filament for camera mount as mounting arms that hold camera might break during insertion.
Please flip "camera_mount.stl" cause it's upside-down :)

These are some stand offs for a Raspberry Pi.

Simple quick little project that anyone can probably design in about a minutes but maybe someone will find these useful if you didn't realized these didn't come with whatever hat you ordered.

I ran a 2-56 tap through the .08 hole and used a (8) 2-56" x 1/8" button head screws to mount them and the hat to the Pi.

You can use a 5.5 mm wrench to hold the stand off if need be... yeah I like to mix metric and imperial so what :)

this is a blow former that blows a heated softened acrylic or similar material, into a dome shape via air pressure from a shop vac or other device.
the red piece in the pics is the softened acrylic piece.
the acrylic must be apprx. .1 in thick but is adjustable because of the screw clamping method.
you place the acrylic on the bottom piece then screw on the top to hold the acrylic in place then turn on air pump.
the bottom has a 2 in. outer diameter , so the hose connect must have a 2 in. inner diameter to mount to it.
i included a stp file so you can adjust the diameter to fit any hose connector you want.

an example is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6zBQDsNUrKc

title: SA-style Keyset for Ortholinear Keyboard w/ MX stems

description.text: This is my custom keyset that I designed for my keyboard. I printed the set all at once, upside-down, by first printing the legends, and then the keyset on top of them. I printed these with eSun PETG for the legends, and Yoyi clear PETG for the actual keys. ABS will also work, but I had issues with them shrinking too much with ABS compared to PETG, making the stems not fit well. This can probably be fixed with an XY stretch of the model.

comments.text: I'm loving printing so far, but I am already having 1 or 2 of each set fail and I'd rather not waste filament printing the whole rows again. Could you upload each keycap individually?
comments.author: SilasK

comments.text: Hi, I'm glad you like them. Unfortunately, the way I designed these sets, it would be extremely time-consuming for me to upload each cap individually. I recommend using a program like meshmixer to delete the keys you don't want want to print, so you can print them 1-2 at a time instead of all at once.
comments.author: SilasK

title: Prusa i3 MK2S x-end-idler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Original Prusa i3 MK2S "x-end-idler" modified for outer diam.22mm T8 nut with belt tensioner and anti-wobble.
There is also a version more similar to original to be used without anti-wobble

Using tensioner as shown in image it gives 4,5mm in regulation and doesn't reduce available print area.

BOM:
Needed by original part (and also for this):

  • 2 M3x10 (DIN 912/ISO 4762)
  • 2 M3 square nuts (DIN 562)
  • 1 M3x18 (DIN 912/ISO 4762)
  • 1 623h bearing (GT2-16)
  • 1 M3 nylock nut (DIN 985/ISO 7040)

Tensioner (new):

  • 1 M3x30 hex head (DIN 933/ISO 4017)
  • 1 M3 square nut (DIN 562)

Anti-wobble (new):

  • 2 M3x10 (DIN 912/ISO 4762)
  • 2 M3 nuts (DIN 934)

September 21th 2017:

  • Added some space inside for a better belt move
  • Little modification to x-end-idler anti-wobble

September 11th 2017:

  • New antiwobble, wrong measures on old version

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed it in ABS but I think PLA can bu used as well.

Supports are not needed but I have a version, without anti-wobble, printed with them and it looks better

Cap and idler body must be printed upside down

For your consideration is a mini combat-bot except instead of a deadly weapon, it has a fidget spinner.

print_settings.Notes:: You want these to print solid since they're so thin. I printed them in ABS to ensure they wouldn't soften up while looking at the sun. ABS has the added benefit of being strong enough to hold up even on the very thing shielding walls surrounding the eye openings.

description.text:
These are goggles designed for use with solar filter film (often sold for telescopes). Along with the printed parts, you'll need:

  • solar filter film
  • 3/8" elastic band (from any fabric store)
  • 1/8-1/4" inner diameter flexible tubing (ventilator / medical pump tubing works well)
  • small bit of felt or other thick-ish fabric to pad the nose piece
  • hot glue

Tools you may find helpful:

  • small files (flat and circular are both helpful here)
  • sand paper

The goggles print in three parts: frame, caps, and what I'll call tensioners. The frames have raised sections around the eye opening for the caps to press-fit onto, sandwiching the solar film in between, then the tensioners are used to thread elastic band through in order to make a head band for keeping the goggles on your head.

You can't really use ABS polishing with these prints, since the dimensions of the parts are very important for them to fit together properly. Instead, I used a combination of files and sand paper, but you'll have to be careful with the goggle shielding since those walls are so thin.

The kids' sized goggles are built from the same OpenSCAD file, but you may have to render a different set of modules to recreate them.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You want these to print solid since they're so thin. I printed them in ABS to ensure they wouldn't soften up while looking at the sun. ABS has the added benefit of being strong enough to hold up even on the very thing shielding walls surrounding the eye openings.

Assembly

The frame prints flat, which means you need to mold it to the contour of your face. This is simply a matter of using a heat source (I used a heat gun) to warm up the bridge of the nose. When the plastic softens up just a bit, you can push the goggles onto your face and bend them into shape. Holding them in place for maybe 20 seconds should allow the plastic to cool and re-harden.

REMEMBER: Only soften up the nose piece. Try not to heat up the shielding around the eye holes, since those walls are so thin they can warp and make it hard to attach the filter caps.

I used the eye caps to cut blanks out of card stock, then trimmed those blanks to just fit inside the walls of the caps. I used these blanks to cut the solar film (the blanks were useful since I was making 8 sets of goggles).

Once the film was cut, I gently laid the film onto the frames, then placed the caps on top and pressed them down onto the frames. CAREFUL: The silver side MUST face out toward the sun! Finally, I hot glued the film to the caps and the caps to the frames, using thin lines of glue and being careful not to accidentally leave strings of the glue crossing the filter film. (Glue is really hard to pull off of the film if you get in the wrong place.)

You'll want to pad the edges that will contact your face, especially since they're very thin. I used some ventilator-style tubing that I had laying around. It was around 1/8" inner diameter, I think. I cut lengths approximately long enough to fit over the sections of the shielding that would contact my face (the tall edges), then used small scissors to cut it open lengthwise. Once opened up, I slipped it over the edges of the shielding and hot glued it down. For the nose piece, I cut a small piece of felt and hot glued that.

Finally, I threaded some 3/8" elastic band through a tensioner, then through the slot on the side of the goggle frame, then back through the tensioner. Repeat for the other side of the elastic band, on the other slot of the goggles, and you're done!

Design Notes

I designed this in OpenSCAD based on some measurements I took from my son's (and my) glasses. It took several iterations to get the sizing right, and after printing the kid-sized goggles I realized that having some shielding surrounding the eyes would improve safety a bit more. The smaller size works well for kids, as long as you pad them well enough and the kid doesn't wear glasses. If you wear glasses, you'll need the larger size (they also work well for kids).

The low cost bluepill board can be converted into a blackmagic probe, which supports JTAG/SWD debugging of many targets.
To do this DFU/blackmagic.bin is needed, can be programmed onto the stm32 using serial bootloader or with an STLINK. I've added the zip as compiling it can be a bit of work, target=STLINK. Pins are as follows:

Pinout (SWD, 6 pin):

  • 1 - Clk - A5
  • 2 - IO - B14
  • 3 - Rst - B0
  • 4 - n/c
  • 5 - 3.3V
  • 6 - Gnd

Pinout (JTAG):

  • TDI - A7
  • TDO - A6
  • TCK - A5
  • TMS - B14

Pinout (serial):

  • Didn't figure out pinout yet, add comment if you know

stlink platform github: https://github.com/blacksphere/blackmagic/blob/master/src/platforms/stlink/platform.h

Dimensions I used are specific to my board, so I'm not sure how well other boards will fit. Pin header retention didn't print to well, but seemed to work OK, glue would help.

I managed to "kill" a SAMD21 using the debugger, still trying to figure out how to recover it. But otherwise it worked well to load .hex bootloader and code.

description.text:
Pinoc Picture / Video Capture System for Binoculars / Telescopes

The full project is here: https://github.com/jdcasey/pinoc

This application is designed to allow Raspberry Pi single-board computers to be mounted on binoculars (or, really anything like that...telescopes for instance). It uses the RPi GPIO interface to read input signals
from momentary buttons (wired to GPIO/BCM 22 & 27), and output status to two LEDs (GPIO/BCM 17 & 24).

Pinoc relies on the use of a Raspberry Pi camera module, which wires directly into the board via ribbon cable. It uses the picamera Python 2 module to interface with the hardware.

Associated Hardware

Raspberry Pis

The large binocular system I came up with uses a Raspberry Pi B+ (or probably, 2 / 3), mainly because I had one laying around. The small binocular system uses a Raspberry Pi Zero / Zero W, mainly because it works well with the compact size (also, they're cheap).

Battery Packs

The battery pack these models are design for is the PNY T2600. It's easy to use and is a convenient way to supply 5V input for the RPi (where other batteries of similar size / capacity are often 3.7V and require extra circuitry to boost the voltage).

Solar Filter Film

If you're gearing up for solar viewing, you'll need film to protect your optics (and your EYES!). You can get that on Amazon. It goes under a heading like Solar Filter Sheet for Telescopes, Binoculars, and Cameras, and usually costs around $20-$30.

Miscellaneous Non-Printed Hardware

  • Hot glue is very useful to keep wires out of trouble (avoid short circuits).
  • Ventilator tubing is useful to line the visor part of the eclipse goggles, where they make contact with your face.
  • Felt is useful to pad the nose piece for the eclipse goggles. You can usually find remnants at fabric stores.
  • M3 screws, or similar.

In the end, I had a bunch of old leftover PC case screws (from PCI slots, etc.) that worked well for putting the different printed parts together, where press-fit wasn't an option. They're about M3, and about 3-3.5mm long. The screws can be used to cut threads directly into the printed parts, which holds together well enough.

Tools

When working with mechanical / precise printed parts, I've found that acetone polishing doesn't really work well. Instead, I use sandpaper and a set of small files (round, half-round, and flat are useful shapes) to get rid of burrs and printer axis chatter that shows up sometimes. It's also useful to soften up the edges a bit, which is important when you consider rigid, sharp plastic edges can cut you...not a great feature for kids!

You may find that the RPi mounting holes are a little too small for M3 screws. To handle this, I used a hand reamer to open them up a little bit. For button plates, I used a push drill with a ~1mm small bit. I've found that hand tools are much easier to control when doing things like this, since they produce results a little bit at a time (and are easier to stop).

CAD Files

The CAD files for this project use two tools: OpenSCAD and FreeCAD. I've used OpenSCAD where the geometries are relatively simple, or where high precision is important. For example, I used OpenSCAD to achieve tolerances required for press-fit parts, while still allowing the model to be parameterized.

I used FreeCAD wherever I had to consume STL files that I didn't create for this project, or when eyeballing worked well enough and having an interactive way to position
parts was more attractive.

The following CAD files are provided:

  • eclipse-goggles.scad - These are not strictly required for using Pinoc, but can be useful if you're gearing up for an eclipse (my original use case for Pinoc)
  • large-pinocs.scad - These are used to mount things to large binoculars, where the barrel has a taper and aren't a strict conical shape but rather a sort of doubled/overlapped cone shape. It includes a button panel you can drill out and use to mount LEDs / buttons for interacting with the RPi.
  • picam-case.scad - This contains the models for mounting the RPi camera board to the eyepiece of the binoculars. It also contains models of solar filter film caps used to fit on the ends of the binocular optics.
  • pinocs-piB.fcstd - This is a FreeCAD file that contains the plate and battery sleeve to mount a RPi B+ / 2B / 3, along with a battery pack, onto a large binocular cuff (from large-pinocs.scad).
  • pinocs.FCStd - Another FreeCAD file, this contains the models necessary to mount a RPi Zero and battery pack to a small, folding binocular system.

In the OpenSCAD files above (*.scad), I've commented the individual modules and parameter sets to make them easier to adjust.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed with a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.185mm layer height, to maximize layer adhesion. I used ABS, with a print bed at 80C and a nozzle temp of 250C. I printed with 3 perimeters (probably overkill) and 3 top/bottom layers. With a layer height like mine, you may want more top/bottom layers to ensure you don't have visible voids (which happened at times with my settings).

None of these parts are really structural in the sense of needing to be strong. Therefore, I tried to minimize material in order to speed up print time (mainly because these were designed incrementally). Pretty much any print style will probably work fine.

author: DC_Engineering

title: Nano Pi2 UMPC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update 12/11/2017 : Experimentation of the Zortrax Z-ESD technical filament.https://store.zortrax.com/zortrax-m200-z-esd

Thanks to Zortrax who sent me, for experimentaton, this filament to print with the Nano Pi2 case.
The interest of this Z-ESD filament is to have protective characteristics against electrostatic discharges.
It is therefore particularly suitable for the integration in plastic boxes of electronic assemblies.

As can be seen in the photo, its appearance is a little brighter than the ABS black proposed by Zortrax. The printing time is longer and it takes 1 hour more, at equivalent thickness, than with the Z-ABS.

With this Z-ESD filament, we find all the characteristics of the Nano Pi2 case in every detail. The surface finish is very finely granular and therefore slightly less smooth than with the Z-ABS.

All in all, a filament as simple to print as standard ABS, but offering superior strength and above all, real antistatic capabilities capable of protecting the electronics.

Update 09/11/2017 : Nano Pi2 docking station/Developpement kit : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2633698

Update 08/11/2017 : Nano Pi2 Webcam & solar charger LCD case : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2633551

Pursuing this exercise of integration and design of cases, here is the intermediate stage towards the development of a complete computer, in the UMPC size, running the Raspberry Pi version 2 board.
In this stage, it is the integration of a smaller screen but while keeping the same screen resolution of screen, which carries the work: the challenge consists here in not exceeding the size been imperative by the keyboard.

On the previous project Raspberry UMPC (https: // www.thingiverse.com / thing:2430252), the interface allowing to connect the screen mobilizes the GPIO port of Raspberry preventing the development of the other projects. That is why it showed itself simpler and more convenient to exploit the HDMI port but in a different format to authorize a big compactness but also an exploitation of the Raspberry port.
This miniaturization is interesting in terms of usesand mobility but more demanding regarding practical realization.

The stage is intermediate because the wireless connections is not integrated, the power is reduced compared with the third version of Pi, there is no sound and the battery allows a use, with WIFI and Bluetooth on, only for about twenty minutes.To finish, it is necessary to manage actively the strong heating of Raspberry Pi3.
Furthermore, this project is more complex and asks for an equipment (soldering for SMT component) and training to succeed in modifying electronic boards and in modifying the connector HDMI without destroying anything.

On this matter, several Raspberry Pi and screens were destroyed by my care to succeed in realizing this project ! That is why I propose, if you plan to realize Nano Pi2 and if you wish to contribute to the development of this project, please download files from Cults3D : https://cults3d.com/fr/gadget/nano-pi2-umpc. Thank you for your help !

Finally, the first Raspberry UMPC project provoked a big interest for this computer to the point that he could possibly become a commercial project under the shape of a DIY kit for example. If you are interested, you can answer the following questionnaire to help to determine if this idea is viable: https://goo.gl/forms/Gfs5fyGjNHq9FU3E3. Thank you for your opinion !

Poursuivant cet exercice d'intégration et de conception de boitiers, voici l'étape intermédiaire vers la mise au point d'un ordinateur complet, au format UMPC, exploitant la carte Raspberry Pi version 2.
Dans cette étape c'est sur l'intégration d'un écran plus petit mais conservant la même résolution d'écran, que porte le travail : le défi consiste ici à ne pas dépasser la taille imposée par le clavier.
Sur le précédent projet Raspberry UMPC (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2430252), l'interface permettant de connecter l'écran mobilise le port GPIO du Raspberry empêchant le développement d'autres projets. C'est pourquoi il s'est révélé plus simple et commode d'exploiter le port HDMI, mais dans un format différent, afin d'autoriser une grande compacité mais également l'exploitation du port du Raspberry.
Cette miniaturisation est intéressante en termes d'usages et de mobilité mais plus exigeante en matière de réalisation pratique.
L'étape est intermédiaire car la connexion sans fils n'est pas intégrée, la puissance est réduite par rapport à la version Pi3, il n'y a pas de son et la batterie ne permet un usage, avec WIFI et Bluetooth, que d'une vingtaine de minutes. Pour finir, il est nécessaire de gérer activement le fort échauffement du Raspberry Pi3.
De plus, ce projet est plus complexe et demande un équipement (soudage de composant CMS) et de l'entrainement pour parvenir à modifier les cartes électroniques et modifier le connecteur HDMI sans rien détruire.

A ce sujet, plusieurs Raspberry Pi et des écrans ont été détruits par mes soins pour parvenir à réaliser ce projet ! C'est pourquoi je propose, si vous planifiez de réaliser le Nano Pi2 et si vous désirez contribuer au développement de ce projet, merci de télécharger les fichiers disponibles sur Cults3D : https://cults3d.com/fr/gadget/nano-pi2-umpc. Merci pour votre aide !

Enfin, le premier projet Raspberry UMPC a provoqué un grand intérêt pour cet ordinateur au point qu'il pourrait éventuellement devenir un projet commercial sous la forme d'un kit par exemple. Si vous êtes intéressé, vous pouvez répondre au questionnaire suivant afin d'aider à déterminer si cette idée est viable : https://goo.gl/forms/Gfs5fyGjNHq9FU3E3. Merci pour votre avis !

Présentation du NANO Pi2 : https://youtu.be/Qcx_SnriwhU

Liste des composants (voir photo) :
Pour réaliser le NANO Pi2, ces composants seront nécessaires :

  • Raspberry Pi2,
  • Un micro clavier bluetooth RT-MWK518BT,
  • un module Powerboost 1000 de Adafruit,
  • Un écran LCD IPS HDMI 4' de Waveshare : http://www.waveshare.com/4inch-hdmi-lcd.htm
  • Une batterie 3,7V 1500 MAh format 752080,
  • 2 connecteurs pour PCB FFC/FPC 20 broches : http://uk.farnell.com/c/connectors/ffc-fpc-board-connectors?DM_PersistentCookieCreated=true
  • 1 cable FFC/FPC 20 broches inversé de 10cm : https://www.aliexpress.com/cheap/cheap-fpc-20-cable.html

Préparation du Raspberry :
A faire avant toute modification du Raspberry : Préparer la carte SD du Raspberry en suivant les instructions proposées par Waveshare pour l'utilisation de l'écran. Pairer le clavier bluetooth, paramétrer la connexion WIFI. Vérifier que tout fonctionne.

(Attention, cette intervention annule la garantie et peut détruire le Raspberry en cas d'erreurs)
Afin d'intégrer le Raspberry dans le boitier, il est nécessaire de le dépouiller de pratiquement tous les connecteurs dont il est pourvu sauf le port GPIO. Pour ce faire, il est possible de suivre les conseils proposés par Adafruit : https://learn.adafruit.com/diet-raspberry-pi/steps. Souder le connecteur FFC/FCP à la place du connecteur HDMI.

Preparation of Raspberry:
To make before any modification of Raspberry : Prepare the SD card of Raspberry by following the instructions proposed by Waveshare for the lcd panel. Paired the bluetooth keyboard, parametrize the WIFI connection. Verify that everything works.

( Watch out, this intervention cancels the guarantee and can destroy Raspberry in case of errors)
To integrate Raspberry into the case, it is necessary to deprive it of practically all the connectors with which it is provided except the GPIO port. To do it, it is possible to follow the advice proposed by Adafruit: https://learn.adafruit.com/diet-raspberry-pi/steps. Solder the FCP/FFP connector instead of the original HDMI one.

Clavier :
(Attention, cette intervention annule la garantie)
Démonter le clavier, décoller et dessouder la batterie (Attention danger de court circuit) de façon à dégager la platine électronique.
Câbler la platine pour l'alimentation en 3,7 volts pris Raspberry Pi aux point PP8 pour 3V3 et PP3 pour la masse.

Keyboard:
( Watch out, this intervention cancels the guarantee)
Tear down the keyboard, peel back and unsolder the battery (Warning danger of short circuit) so as to release the electronic deck.
Cable the deck for the supply in 3,7 volts taken by the Raspberry Pi board on Pad PP8 for 3V3 and PP3 for GND.

Ecran :
Préparer l'écran en décollant le paneau LCD (Attention très fragile : casse facilement...). Nettoyer les deux surfaces : platine et écran en ôtant le ruban adhésif. Supprimer tous les connecteurs, souder le connecteur FFC/FPC à la place du HDMI. Retailler la platine électronique de l'écran. Garder le petit interrupteur et câbler l'allumage du retro éclairage. Voir photos.

Screen:
Prepare the screen by unsticking the LCD panel (very fragile Warning : break very easily...). Clean both surfaces: board and LCD backward by removing the adhesive tape. Deprive all the connectors, solder the connector FFC / FPC instead of the HDMI. Recut the electroni board. Keep the micro switch and cable the ignition of the backlight. See photos.

Batterie :
(Attention : respecter les précautions d'usage et manipulation des batteries Li-Ion qui peuvent prendre feu et exploser en cas de mauvaise manipulations)
Supprimer le connecteur de batterie, souder les fils de la batterie à la place. Utiliser le petit interrupteur et le cabler pour commander la mise sous tension du powerboost. Câbler l'ensemble selon le mode d'emploi proposé par Adafruit pour son module.

Battery:
( Warning : respect usual precautions and manipulation of batteries Li-Ion which can catch fire and explode in case of bad manipulations)
Delete the connector of battery, solder the battery wires instead. Use the small switch and cable it to command the switched on of the powerboost. Cable the set according to the instructions for use proposed by Adafruit for his module.

Montage : suivre la vidéo sur le making of
Assembling : follow the making of video : https://youtu.be/8U7VZhNOIM4

Si vous n'avez pas d'imprimante 3D, les pièces peuvent être commandées sur Shapeways :

title: Motor Guard for Upgraded KingKing 90GT Micro Quadcopter

description.text:
A few months ago, I modified my KingKong 90GT to make room for larger propellers. You can move the motors outward by quite a few millimeters if you avoid the two innermost screw holes on the frame, and you're willing to use only two screws on each motor.

This works surprisingly well. You can upgrade from the stock 2" props to 2.5" props. Flight times and thrust both go up. It is a free upgrade, and I'm very pleased with the results.

I've essentially turned my KingKong 90GT into a 105GT.

Most of the time, I was flying over grass or dirt, and the hardest thing I'd crash into would be a tree. In those cases, all I ever managed to do was break a prop.

The last few weeks, we've been flying in a new parking lot, and I've been crashing into the concrete. Most of the time this happens when I run out of battery, but every now and then it happens because I forget that the KingKong 90GT doesn't have nearly as much thrust as my real racing drone.

This modification leaves the motors quite exposed without any carbon fiber to protect them. I recently managed to have enough of a voltage drop that I fell from the sky near the top of a power loop. I was up high enough that it took about four seconds to hit the ground, and I severely bent a motor.

Motors are cheap, but I figured I could add a little protection to my modified KingKong 90GT. These little discs extend past the base of the motor, and the little nubbins on top are just about as thick as the carbon fiber frame. This allows you to use four screws--I sized this for 7mm screws, since those come with every set of 2.4" and 2.5" props.

In a crash, this bumper will hit the ground first. Using four screws should help hold the bottom of the motor in place, and the bumper should transfer most of the shock to the frame.

I've crashed a few times, and they seem to be working well. The part I uploaded is 2mm wider than the bumpers I'm running on my own drone.

I printed mine in ABS. We'll see just what sort of crashes they can stand up to.

  • The KingKong 90GT Micro Drone Is Bananas
  • KingKong 90GT Upgrades

title: RecklessRobbies Catan Long water edges - Split

description.text: The Water edges from RecklessRobbies Warcraft Catan board wouldn't fit on my little printer, so I split them in half with a puzzle join so that they would fit on a 12cm x 12cm bed. Also allows for randomization (somewhat) of the port locations as the split is in the same place on all of them. I've set them up so you can either print them together or individually (so there's three files for each edge). In hindsight I should have made the split one section further so that they don't line up with the join on the tiles, but by the time I realized I couldn't be bothered...

So I took Pezxy's S8 model, used Blender to Decimate it with a factor of 0.2 (the original had something like 400k polygons or something crazy), and scaled it up to match the published exterior dimensions of the Note8. The purpose of this is purely so you can print it out and put it in your pocket to help you decide if it's too big or not. As soon as someone posts a real model of a Note8 I will delete this model.

title: Bike holder for samsung Galaxy S7 Edge and E-Thinker 10000mAh powerbank V.4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
(This is version 4 of the holder, I made some small adjustments to make it easier to print without support, enjoy!)

(OBS: if you want this bike holder without the powerbank compartment please follow this link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2514147 )

Bought a new e-bike (EcoRide) and wanted a holder for my phone (Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge with Spigen SlimArmor case.) so that I can use Navigation and S-health, as navigation with the phone in the pocket is a pain, not to mention dangerous.

I also have a E-thinker 10.000 mAh powerbank, and tought that if I combine the two I can also charge my phone at the same time, since using GPS consumes alot of power.

The holder is tied down with a couple of zip ties, see pictures.

Here is a link to the Spigen SlimArmor case I use: https://www.spigen.com/products/galaxy-s7-edge-case-slim-armor?variant=11972954241

title: Ultimaker build platform dial gauge bracket

description.text: This is a bracket to hold a depth gauge to the extruder head of an ultimaker 3d printer. This allows easy and quick levelling of the build table.  The bracket is sized to fit a gauge I found in a box of junk in my loft. The gauge measures deflection to an accuracy of 1/1000 of an inch, so in theory I can get my build table that level. In practice, I probably get 1/200 of an inch, but that's easily accurate enough to improve my prints.

Print the bracket and the flange, and drill the holes. The small holes should be M3, the larger hole on the flange should be sized to fit whatever bolt fits your gauge.  
Once you have drilled the holes, superglue 2 nuts (with washers) to the base - see the pics for clarification.  this allows quick removal of the flange with gauge still attached, for printing.  
The base can then be fitted to the long bolts that form the structure of the extruder assembly. Fit it on the opposite side to the fan.  
The dial gauge should be bolted to the flange, and the flange can then be bolted to the base - and you're good to go.
Once you've levelled the build table, you'll need to remove the flange with the gauge still attached (leaving the base still fixed the the extruder head). Otherwise the gauge will hit the side of the printer during the print.
I printed this at 30% infill, layer thickness 0.2mm or so.

title: Linear Bearing for 8mm Smooth Rod with 608 Bearings - Less Filament

description.text:
Hallo everyone, this is a remix of the ZNahum`s Linear Bearing.

All sides are 6-8 mm too long, so i decided to make it smaller to use less filamet.
I also make a 30° Angel to use less Filament.

Use M8 x 25mm Screws and put them in from the Round side.
Use some washer left and right from the 608 Bearing.

Because there is just 1 Bearing on two sides, the Smooth Rod could move in any direction. That sometimes no problem but i want to make it more straight, so i added 3 Bearings in the second Version.

I haven`t printed it yet, but i think it should be everything ok.

description.text:
If you want to use a rigid coupler instead of the spring coupler your threaded rod needs to be absolutely parallel to the z rod. To achieve this my version of the Z-Motor-Holder uses oblongs to allow a fine adjustment in the x plane
I recommend using decouplers for the motor. The results are astonishing. No more wobble, shifts and other unwanted artifacts. Leveling is much more precise because the Z axis follows each motor move directly and without stretching or squeezing a spring.

I only needed to change the right side because on the left it was already perfect.

If you need a left side, simply mirror the STL in your slicer

AM8

title: X-axis brace for Maker Select v2/Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
So the other day, while printing something that required the extruder to move left & right rapidly, I noticed that the belt had some twist in it, because the pulleys weren't parallel with each other. I found that since I had my X-axis belt adjusted to a higher tension than stock, the belt was pulling the X carriages in towards one another, causing the belt to be slightly miss-aligned. I decided to come up with these X-braces to properly align the X belt, and make the carriages much more ridged, as you can see in the .gifs. I don't really think it improved print quality a whole lot, but I like having the belt not ride on the edges of the stepper/pulley.

I made them so they snapped in place pretty snug, but I also put in a hole for a set screw(PC case fan screw) just in case.

Gifs:
Stock: https://i.imgur.com/Zgp3FeT.gifv
Braced: https://i.imgur.com/YJJTFs0.gifv

Also, I'm fairly certain that this will interfere with a rear mounted cooler, such as the CiiiCooler.

Required materials:

11.75"(~300mm) of 5/16" threaded rod
4, 5/16" nuts
2, PC case fan screws (Optional)

title: Bender head
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
** update **
I tweaked the model twice. In V2 the head is a tiny bit longer, the front edge of his goggles are of consistent thickness (unlike in V1), and the lips have a tiny slope, so that it is possible to print the entire model WITHOUT supports. I printed a 27cm tall version of V2, perfectly without supports and without infill, with 0.3mm layer height and 4 walls (1.6mm). See the pink bender.
Then i decided to further improve on that model, and make Bender's goggles more like the actual goggles in the cartoon. Not totally rounded around the eyes, and more flat on the side (see the comparison pictures between V1 and V3)
I added two prints of the V3 model. Both printed with Cura's fuzzy skin option. The larger one (40cm) i painted with black outdoor paint. The fuzzy skin effect did cause small gaps on the top of the head (neither were printed with infill). These gaps did not occur with a normal print.

I wanted to print a large model on my new CR-10, so i checked out the Bender head people are printing... but on closer inspection, i didn't really like that model much. The resolution of the mesh is low, making it blocky. The antenna is very abnormal and course imo. The teeth do not match the fine lines of Bender's teeth in the cartoon. And his goggles don't actually stick out much... I understand all of these design decisions were made in order to print the model quickly and without supports, but i rather have a model i like, than one i don't like but can print without supports or print a few minutes faster (cura says there's a 15 minutes difference for a 15cm tall print between both models). So i designed a new model from scratch. And what program better suited to make a Bender model, than Blender!

Either way, the small print (15cm) in the picture, was printed WITHOUT supports, with 4 walls. The taller one (20cm) had a problem with the extruder (you can see a line about 3/4th in the print), i printed that one with 3 walls and with supports. Both were printed with zero infill. I'm guessing for the larger prints, it's best to use supports, but maybe i need to test some more.

I'm pleased with the model, i think it captures the essence of Bender better then the other model, but it may come at a price.

RECAP (edit):
You shouldn't need supports if your printer is dialed in and if you're using enough walls. The large (27cm V2 model) pink bender (see picture) was printed without supports, with 0% infill, and with 4 walls on a 0.3mm layer height. It took little under 10 hours to print this model and took about 180 grams of plastic.
Feedback is much appreciated!!

V1 = original attempt, better with some supports
V2 = improved on the original, doesn't need supports, even goggle edge thickness
V3 = same improvements as V2 but with a new goggle design, more like the cartoon
I checked the original model by cerberus333, then i googled some images of Bender and decided what i wanted to improve. Then i started modelling in Blender. I mainly used the boolean modifier.

comments.text:
Finally, Bender model i like! Thanks! As you posted in your description - i've had same feeling about other Bender models like you. So this should be my next print.
Thanks again!

title: Ozo the Bear, Stickerless! (for multi-extruder printers)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a multicolor remix of the elegant Ozo puzzle model. The stickers are now built in!

This model has 7 parts:

  • Top left (up to 6 colors)
  • Top right (up to 6 colors)
  • Center left (2 colors)
  • Center right (2 colors)
  • Bottom left (2 colors)
  • Bottom right (2 colors)
  • A hidden pin that connects the left and right halves

I plan to work on the "panda" version as well.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in PETG on the Prusa MK2 with the multi-material upgrade. Ozo's parts move freely and the puzzle is fun. I used Slic3r Prusa edition to slice the print.

I printed both pins. I'm not sure which one I used; one of them fit better. In PETG the pins feel rather strong.

Don't forget: once you put the pin in both sides, you might not be able to disassemble Ozo without breaking something. Double-check your assembly and save the pin for last.

title: Duet wifi bracket for robo3d R1+
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This bracket will fit a duet wifi board into the robo3d R1+ 3d printer. Use a PCI slot fan and Dremel down the long part that sticks out. Use two screws to attach the bracket to where the RAMPS board originally was. Put a dot of epoxy on the part of the board where there isn't a screw, on the nub, after screwing the duet on in the other 3 holes. Drill holes in the bottom plate under where the PCI slot fan is. Remove the old ramps fan.

There are no heatsinks on the duet. Instead, the entire board is a heatsink, so this bracket acts like a duct blowing air under the board.

remixed_from.author: PistonPin
remixed_from.title: MicroCube z-axis for NEMA 14 stepper motors with 608zz bearing

title: MicroCube z-axis for NEMA 14 Reuses everything else

description.text:
I wanted to use a Nema 14 motor for the z-axis and found about PistonPin's remix for a Nema 14 however it separated the smooth rods by 10mm which means I had to re-print a lot of hours to make it work. Thankfully he shared the OpenSCAD source and I simply modified it to make the Nema 14 work with 70mm wide apart smooth rods as in the original mount for the MicroCube's z-axis.

One thing to keep in mind is that some NEMA 14 have wider mount holes on the top that may be too wide for the default smooth rods separation. It happened to me, and what I did to circumvent this was simply to unscrew the NEMA 14 and rotate the top plate 90 degrees as shown in the photos. This way everything else should work.

I haven't tested this yet as I'm about 80% into my MicroCube build but so far, it looks promising.

This is a 24cm-diameter ferris wheel. It is designed to sit in a fixed position, and it has 60 platforms (30 on each side), each 2.5cm square. The platforms can be used to put figurines or anything else that can fit.

There are four distinct types of pieces. You need 4 each of the two orientations of the quarter wheel, and 1 each of the stand, male wheel connector, and female wheel connector.

The included pieces are sufficient to make the ferris wheel stand up on its own. However, to increase the stability, I added small pieces of velcro to the flat sides of the wheel pieces. I also made room for you to insert a 1/2-inch ceramic magnet into the wheel connector to increase the connecting force and make the two pieces less likely to break apart.
I designed all of the parts using FreeCAD. This is one of my first custom designs, I am grateful to the FreeCAD community for their help in learning how to use their wonderful software.

print_settings.Notes:: Print the part in the orientation it is downloaded in, to ensure proper fit. Best to print at a layer height that will provide good layer adhesion, as the bottom portion of the bracket is relying on this for support.

title: Ikea OBSERVATOR Bracket for Closetmaid Wire Shelving

description.text:
This bracket was designed to allow an Ikea OBSERVATÖR wire basket to be attached to a ClosetMaid Close Mesh Wire Shelf. These baskets can be had for around $3 USD, which is a bit cheaper than the ClosetMaid version of these baskets.

Feel free to leave a comment if you feel the design could be improved, or remix the file yourself.

Assembly:

Start by hanging the two "fingers" of the basket on the ClosetMaid shelf. Then snap the top part of the bracket to the ClosetMaid wire shelf. While supporting the basket, the bracket can be slid on the ClosetMaid shelving towards the Ikea basket and attached to it.

More than two brackets could be used to better support the basket.

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Print the part in the orientation it is downloaded in, to ensure proper fit. Best to print at a layer height that will provide good layer adhesion, as the bottom portion of the bracket is relying on this for support.

author: turfyman

print_settings.Notes:: This is a fairly easy print, no special settings required aside from support for a couple of sections which could be cut out post printing if you choose. The PMU is a very tight fit and is intended to have a clear diffuser between it and the frame. The PMU's plastic case and heat shrink must be removed for it to be installed. A dab of rubber cement or something similar will be required to keep the PMU and FC in place. All wires can be run under the FC and attached to the rails for a very clean install.

description.text:
An organised mount for Naza with the new version PMU/LED combo. Also has a provision for two 1.65mm brass power rails in place of a power distribution board as well as a camera mount for an Eachine MC-02 AIO camera. You will need 300mm of brass for the power rails, 4 m3x10-12mm bolts, naza m lite or v2 with the combined PMU/LED and an mc 02 camera or similar.

This was designed on the clone frame available from ebay for around 10USD. When built with 2403 2300kv motors, FVT little bee 20a esc's and a 1300mah 3s 30c pack you can expect flight times between 6 and 10 minutes.

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

~.08

Infill:

10-100%

Notes:

This is a fairly easy print, no special settings required aside from support for a couple of sections which could be cut out post printing if you choose. The PMU is a very tight fit and is intended to have a clear diffuser between it and the frame. The PMU's plastic case and heat shrink must be removed for it to be installed. A dab of rubber cement or something similar will be required to keep the PMU and FC in place. All wires can be run under the FC and attached to the rails for a very clean install.
The longitudinal holes for the power rails will likely need reaming as they are designed with very tight tolerances for a friction fit.

Just another filament spool holder. If your filament's spool has a large hole, you can skip printing SpoolHolder3Shaft and use a short length of 1/2" or 3/4" PVC pipe.

Print 1 each SpoolHolder3Left and SpoolHolder3Right, and 2 each of SpoolHolder3CrossBrace Optionally, print 1 SpoolHolder3Shaft.

Assembly is pretty obvious.

You should notice that the V for the shaft is offset from the center of the sides and that one side of the V is more vertical than the other. The more vertical side of the V should be toward your printer to reduce the possibility of the spool being pulled off of the fixture.

This thing has moved to Youmagine https://www.youmagine.com/designs/simple-flute so I don't also get sued by Stratasys... Very basic flute that I made for the kids after having problems with many other flute models. PS: it's kind of loud... Update: "flute08.stl" is the version I use the most these days. It has a tiny square break-away part that supports the overhang of the corner. Makes for prettier prints and less cleanup.

Turns out that making a flute is a lot harder than you would think, but after a long weekend fiddling, I found a design that is simple, prints fast and works all the time. This model works fine on my Ultimaker, but it should print successfully on other printers. The crux really is getting the bottom of the "gap" sharp and fine, so it divides the airstream successfully. Due to this, there is a limit to how small you can make it.
To make other tones, experiment with scaling the flute. If you print with PLA and have retraction/comb available in your slicer, use it for less cleanup. You'll see this as it prints, but there's an "island" in the design that creates a few "strings". If you don't have this, the strings are easy to remove with just a par of tweezers. For ABS, this is not a problem at all.
To avoid the ever-annoying question of what flute belongs to who, it added the initials of each kid that got it (as seen in the image).
Update: confirmed that it prints nicely on both MakerGear M2 and Printrbot Jr.

description.text:
/!\ WARNINGS FOR STUPID/LITIGIOUS PEOPLE: Gun intended for recreational purposes. Do not use in public. Use adequate protection. I am not liable for any damages resulting from improper use of this toy gun. /!\

Here is the PBP-0 (Pull Back Pistol) Adieu, a compact, decent-looking Lego gun that actually shoots bullets! Sure, the range isn't the best, the mag is unreliable, and there's the occasional jam, but I have to start somewhere, and I'm actually pretty proud of the end result.

While this might be considered a failure by professional Lego gun standards, it is just an experiment.

STATS
Fire mode: Manual
Action: Pullback
Capacity: 4 rounds
Range:
Ammo: Bullet (2M axle in 2M axle connector), bullet (2M pin in pin connector)

FEATURES
Sprung magazine
Mag can be inserted and removed without taking one's hand off of the gun's grip
Detachable stock
Ammo storage in stock
Detachable silencer
Connection points on top for accessories
More resistance to bad aim caused by holding the gun "gangsta style" (sideways)

TIPS

  • The mag can be difficult to load; make sure each round is secured before resuming loading.
  • Since the silencer is just for decoration, it does nothing to hide the fact that the PBP-0's report is comparable to a nail gun's.

Mag insertion instructions:
1) Prime bolt.
2) Hook mag retention hooks into gaps in mag (or use tab to pull back hooks).
3) Pull on hooks, allowing the mag to be inserted completely.

Rubber band springing instructions:
Picture 2: Thread the band through the hole of the 90° cross block.
Pictures 3 and 4: Hook either end of the band onto the pin connector (followed by the other), but make sure the way in which this step is executed is symmetrical (identical for both sides).
Picture 5: For the mag, insert the follower (with an extra-long rubber band hooked around its ball) into the mag before assembly of the mag is completed. With the follower secured, hook the other end of the band around the ball at the mag's bottom. In the picture, the band has been moved out of the way for clarity's sake, but make sure it is centred for optimal performance.

Mechanism inspired by YouTuber CozShot. Please don't sue.

author: JustInTimetoNerf

description.text:
I had 3 of the plastic cases that the Tevo Titan clone comes in. I thought they would make good storage containers for my nozzles, heat-breaks and Blocks.

1-V6, 1-Volcano, and 1-Heat Block Insert should all fit into the container. The Short Shell insert can be substituted for a Volcano insert. 2 Tall Shell inserts will fit top to bottom in the case.

I made a little tool that helps to pull the inserts out. It works ok, but could be improved upon. If anyone has suggestions on improvements, please post in the comments.The inserts in the photo were all printed @ 15% infill; 1 wall; .26 layer height, and all the nozzles
fit nicely in the holes.

The Nozzle Inserts are for standard 7mm hex E3D style nozzles.
The Heat Block Insert Holds 6 V6 Blocks and 6 Volcano Blocks.
Mine are all clones, not sure if this will affect the sizing on genuine E3D Parts.

For the Volcano Low and V6 Low, the channels are level with the hex part of the nozzle.
Volcano Flush and V6 Flush are as the name says, flush with the tips of the nozzles.
The Pull Tool "Vertical", adds a cross section for support, but this is untested as of now, feel free to print and try it.

MPSM

print_settings.Notes:: This must be printed using nylon filament.  PLA or ABS would simply produce a solid ornament.  Nylon is needed for the flexibility.

description.text:
This is a very basic and perhaps unsophisticated fly swatter. My aim was to make it as simple as possible and not introduce any fitting problems. So there is no pushing one part into another, etc. The protruding spigots of the locking washer locate in the swatter and handle at the same time. A very basic nut and bolt fixing holds it all together.
You could easily buy a cheap swatter, but this was my first attempt at printing in nylon. As I also needed a fly swatter, I was testing out the flexibility of nylon and it seemed to work fine.

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

normal

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This must be printed using nylon filament. PLA or ABS would simply produce a solid ornament. Nylon is needed for the flexibility.

Assembly

The assembly is very simple. The locking washer locates through six holes of the swatter, sufficient for the handle to then locate on the locking washer. The two parts are held together by a nut and bolt.
The hole matrix of the swatter is not symmetrical. For the locking washer to be fitted and be positioned exactly in the centre, the wider band of the swatter should be facing away from the handle (see photo).

comments.author: hm23

comments.text: Es tut mir leid, aber ich muss auf Englisch antworten.  I fully understand your concern about the food chain for non-human creatures.  This fly swatter is for the flies (musca domestica) that enter my house and buzz around at high speed, often straight at me.  I'm sorry but if I could tell them to leave I would do so.  I never kill bees, bumble bees or wasps and open the window to encourage their departure.  If necessary I will catch them live and then release them.  I give spiders full reign of the house and if one appears I just ignore it.  I don't like ants in the house however.  I have lived abroad at one time when there were a greater variety of insects invading the home – cockroaches, fleas, praying mantis, etc.  The bread sold in that country had weevils baked in the rolls and appeared as black spots.  If they weren't dead when the bread mixture was made then it was death by baking.  Okay I kill flies but humans kill other humans without any conscience and often by torture and with no other interest than to gain power.  I think that for the few flies I might kill – and I haven't done so yet – my fly swatter is as least a discouragement for them to remain, since they fly so fast it's not easy to catch them anyway.
comments.author: hm23

Ich möchte Ihnen keines wegs zu nahe treten, mir ging es darum mal darüber nachzudenken und evtl. mit etwas Zeitaufwand die Fliegen / Insekten aus dem Fenster zu lassen.
Wenn ich auf dem Lande Auto fahre, da gibt es kaum Fliegen auf der Windschutzscheibe, früher war das ganz anders, da waren es sehr viele.
Heute muß man schon darüber nachdenken die Vögel auch im Sommer, z.Bsp. wenn es stark geregnet hat zu füttern.

Follow me & my projects: twitter.com/MoceriMike
Video of the event: http://youtu.be/tuCeDbiXMiE

Mike Moceri and Tom Burtonwood collaborated on a project that premiered May 26th at The Southside Hub of Production for the exhibition "On Making Things Matter". We 3d scanned (with the Kinect, Reconstructme + Netfabb) visitors at the opening reception and then 3d Printed them with a MakerBot Thing-O-Matic. All the "portraits" we scanned are uploaded to Thingiverse to share with teh internets. We have also scanned portions of the exhibition and the interior of the building and we will be installing 3d prints of these vignettes over the course of the exhibition. SHoP (South Side Hub of Production)
On Making Things Matter: Strategies For Preservation
curated by Laura Shaeffer, John Preus and Alberto Aguilar 5638 S. Woodlawn Ave. Chicago, Illinois 60637 Opening Reception: Saturday, May 26th, 6:00 -- 11:00 pm
Exhibition Runs: May 26 -- July 15, 2012
I print mine at .27mm, 120mm/s accelerated, 7% infill

description.text: This is the kickstand for the Spigen case on my Nexus 6. The original piece is really flimsy and I managed to break it (I'm surprised it lasted as long as it did). This replacement can be much stronger than the original depending on the filament used. I used HTPLA and I already feel like it's an improvement.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

As small as you can

Infill:

At least 50%

Notes:

I printed this using a .1mm layer height and 100% infill with HTPLA. It is just as good, if not better than the original. I would recommend using a strong plastic (like PETG, ABS, or a strong PLA) and slow print speeds as the part is small and needs to be somewhat strong.

Also, I would recommend printing the part with the outside (where "Spigen" was on the original part) on the bed/facing down. I printed it with no supports this way and there were only minor overhang problems which can be fixed with a hobby knife.

title: Scope Side Focus Wheel (Parallax Wheel) for scope Falcon Merlin 4-14x56 IR

description.text:
Side Focus Wheel (Parallax Wheel) for scope Falcon Merlin 4-14x56 IR.

The wheel is a redesign of Aeon Side Focus Wheel ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1608534 ).
I made it fit exactly the scope Falcon Merlin 4-14x56, so it may not be suitable for different scopes.

Inner diameter is 44.2mm.
Outer diameter is 141.5mm.
Thickness: 10mm

The wheel fits tightly in winter period and a little bit easy in summer. But it's safe for scope :)
Has marks to position the wheel on a handle (marks placed against eagle's wings), but your scope may have eagle rotated for different angle by manufacturer, so pay attention to it.

You can print the test wheel to see how it fits your scope and save plastic and your print time.

title: Hypercube Bushing Probe Inductive Sensor Mount

description.text:
Hi,

since my sensor was on the side of my fan duct it collides with my Y stepper motor. So I decided to mount it to the back. I used Tech2C's dual bushing holder and added a mount für 12mm inductive and capacitive proximity sensors.

Marlin need to be configured as follows:

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0  // X offset: -left  +right  [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 63  // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 64

If you are interested in the pictured fan duct, see
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2517118

remixed_from.title: Amiga 500 Gotek USB disk drive emulator base

title: Amiga 3000 Gotek V2 USB disk drive emulator base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Sep-14-2017 (Update)
Added a "v2" STL version which moves the USB port more centered to the floppy drive opening, widened the original 3 digit LED display cutout and moved it back slightly to now support an OLED display for use with firmwares such as FlashFloppy, please see the documentation of FlashFloppy for more details but the OLED type is a common inexpensive one found on ebay "0.91" IIC I2C Serial SPI OLED LCD Display 128x32 3.3V/5V AVR PIC STM32 Arduino"

(Sep 3, 2017) This is a remix of the fantastic Amiga 500 Gotek USB disk drive emulator base but for the Amiga 3000 desktop computer. Please see the original by CrazyBob for additional details.

To mount this in an Amiga 3000 you will need the metal drive sled in that comes with the Amiga 3000. I simply screwed this gotek sled to the drive plate from underneath (where the little metal tabs are) up thru the plate's screw holes into the plastic sled. (the same if you were placing a hard drive into the metal sled).

(the last photo shows the --unpublished at this time-- LCD floppy bay cover, that works like the original floppy bay cover (clicks into the drive slot) and is removable allowing you to use your original floppy drive if desired (configured as DF1 with the Gotek as DF0).

For aesthetics I recommend using a mini OLED display which will fit in the original gotek LED display cutout, therefor not requiring the external LCD clip-on drive cover holder. http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/302110929185

I also HIGHLY recommend flashing your Gotek with ‎Keir Fraser's excellent "FlashFloppy" gotek firmware (much better than the old Cortex and works like HxC but free to use), it supports LCD displays and floppy sounds!
https://github.com/keirf/FlashFloppy

Printer:

Craftbot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used 0.3 (you can use any)

Infill:

50% for strength (your choice)

Notes:

As the drive eject button is rather small, I suggest using supports to have it print out nicely.

Printed on a CraftBot 1 in about 1h 30m at 80mm/s

comments.text: Can you Please move things around so that the USB port is centered in the middle of the floppy drive opening.  Also, can you make the eject button fill the hole a little better?  I'm ready to have one printed out as soon as things get perfected.

comments.text: I added an updated version that moves the USB port more to the center (it not perfect as I have to allow space for the OLED screen) but its pretty close to center as I can get.

Learned so much during this design on how to use the displacement modifier in blender.

title: 3D-printed scale model of EUR pallet (made of wood-based filament)

description.text:
A 1:10 scale model version of an EUR shipping pallet 3D printed with wood fiber-based filament, which gives the model a very natural wood-like appearance.
The model is available in both original full-size (1200 x 800 mm) and a scaled down version to a tenth of the size (120 x 80 mm). For anyone who wishes to re-model the pallet in CAD software, a STEP-file is also available.
You can use this 3D print as a decorative artefact or for instance use it as coaster to rest your Friday-evening after-work beer! :)
For more information about EUR pallets check out this Wikipedia article:
  • http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EUR-pallet

    By Creative Tools

    Home - Youtube - Things - #3DBenchy - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Instructables - Instagram - Pinterest - Flickr - LinkedIn"

The 3D files of this pallet are available in both fully-assembled and flattened-out board on a build plate.
  • Instructions: http://bit.ly/1cdYphd
  • http://youtu.be/lzgveRIGJG8
  • The wood filament: http://bit.ly/1eEXaE2

description.text:
Got the idea from on on here. Will get the url and update later.  
Made this real thin for quick printing and low plastic use. I may increase the thickness and upload it later. It printed o.k. but i think you would have to paint it to make it true water tight. I was going to paint mine any ways so didn't make any difference.  
Find you a cork to plug the top. I will get to the hardware store and find the right size to get for it and update then.  
The base fit great on mine, yet you may have to put a hair dryer on it and squeeze in the tabs a bit to make a good tight fit.  
Drop you a small piece of cantaloupe, water-melon or maybe a few pinches of banana and stand back and watch the fun.   
You can even string a twine thru the cork and hang it up somewhere. I may try that myself.  
Enjoy, Rick.

author: DonGiotto

description.text: Very easy stuff ... but usefull !!!

Consider supporting me by sending me a tip on thingiverse or PayPal.

paypal.me/jackwaterfall

Make sure to post a make if you print one!

Updates

03/09/2017 - First release.

What Is It?

If you are upgrading your Prusa i3 hotend mount or extruder assemnly, you'll need some way of mounting it to your x rods. Theis x-carriage attaches to the x rods using linear bearings. This x-carriage uses the same four hole mounting system that is used on the Prusa I3 rework 1.5 kit and most designs on thingiverse, so you'll need to print off a compatible x-carriage mount.

My Bowden X-Carriage Mount for E3D V6: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2023947

This design uses a clamp to hold the bearings in place rather than using flimsy zip ties.

Notes

Thanks to Josef Prusa. I took inspiration for this design from the Prusa MK2s x-carriage.

description.text:
After a night of prototyping and redoing the box due to over-sizing, I finally made a box that should be able to hold your Astrologian tarot cards safely. If there's enough requests or post for an update/edit, I can possibly add additional features like a belt clip. As for now, I'll leave it as is since it was made as a gift for a dear friend. I removed their name and left the logo on the front of the box. Top clips into the bottom without any sanding, should be a snug enough fit to slide in and out with a small bit of force.
If you use transparent filament you'll get a nice semi see-through effect as shown in my pictures without needing to do anything.

description.text:
Mount for the Harbor Freight Luminar Work 120 LED Rechargeable Under Hood Work Light Item #60793 for a Weather Guard truck tool box. Mounts to the lid support cross member with 1/4 - 20 bolts and rivnuts.

UPDATE: These mounts also work with the new Braun under hood work light Item # 63990

The new Braun light is a nice upgrade, check out this video I made comparing it to the old Luminar Work light. https://youtu.be/5CWR_aZdHWQ
